captions.text: # 5. Vikings

What would a Viking be without his trusty
battle helmet and its impressive horns? The
answer is: a more historically accurate viking.

Think, for a moment about wearing headgear
like that into battle: the horns are just

easy targets for your opponent to hit and
knock off your helmet.

Or, if you strap on your helmet, now your
opponent has a convenient lever with which

to drag you to the ground and something to
hold onto while slitting your throat.

Horned helmets are a terrible idea, which
is why archeologists have never found them

at viking battle sites and there's no evidence
that they were ever used.

It was poets and artists -- people not known
for caring about facts and reality -- who

gave the Vikings their silly hats during the
late 1800s, long after the vikings could 'correct'
their misconceptions.
4. Lady Godiva

The story of this 11th century English noblewoman
is that her mean husband the Earl raised taxes

on the townspeople of Coventry which Lady
Godiva -- and not surprising the locals -- thought
were too high.

She badgered her husband and he conceded in
exasperation to lower the taxes if she rode

through town naked -- assuming that she never
would, but she did.

Because people don't likes taxes -- even though
they're how civilization is purchased -- Lady

Godiva's story lives on notably in the Godiva
logo and in popular songs.

But while Lady Godiva was a real person and
Coventry is a real town there is no record

of her nude ride from the time when it happened
-- so we can assume the story is false. Just

as with the Vikings, again poets and artists
are to blame, who made up the tale long after
Lady Godiva's death.
3. Napoleon

Famously this tiny, tiny general -- perhaps
to compensate for his short stature -- took

control of France greatly expanded its influence
and dubbed himself emperor.

Napoleon's official height was indeed 5 foot
2 inches but at the time French inches were

longer than English inches, so doing the unit
conversion, Napoleon's height should have

been reported as 5'7 in England's imperial
units -- which is short by today's standard

but was average or slightly above average
in the early 1800s.

However England, with it's eternal love for
all things French, didn't care and went the

Napoleon-is-so-short-LOL version of the story
in newspapers and cartoons.

Meanwhile, Napoleon was busy introducing the
Metric System to France and the wider world

to standardize measurements so this sort of
confusion would never happen again -- and

thankfully the whole world now uses metric.
Mostly. Sort of.
2. Roman Vomit

Ah, the Roman empire, so great and powerful,
but corrupted by decadence from within. And

what could be a better symbol of that decadence
than the Vometorum: where Romans, after stuffing

themselves with delicious foods, could vomit
them all up to make room to feast anew.

Vometoria are real but this idea of them is
not, though confusion is understandable because

their name -- Vomit-orium -- seems to make
their purpose so clear.

Even if for some reason you know latin -- perhaps
because you live in a country that insists

you waste hundreds of hours of your life learning
a dead, useless language -- this knowledge

still won't help you because the root word
'vomitum' means 'to spew forth'.

So what is it really? If you've ever been
to a big stadium, like say, the ones made

by the romans, you have already used a vometorium.
This is what the vometoria are -- the passageways

that lets lots of people enter or exit at
once. The people are what spews forth in the
vometoria, not the contents of the people.
1. Columbus

There is so very much wrong with the common
retelling of the story of Christopher Columbus

that it's hard to know where to begin, but
the biggest misconception is that everyone

else thought the world was flat, but Columbus
was the only guy smart enough to know that
it's round.

It makes a daring story, but knowledge of
a spherical earth goes back to at least 5,000

BC that's six and a half thousand years before
Columbus set sail -- and that knowledge was

never lost to western civilization. In 200
BC Eratosthenes calculated Earth's circumference

and his estimate was still well know and being
used in Columbus's time.

The argument Columbus had with queen Isabella
was not over the shape of the earth, but of

its size. Columbus estimated the Earth was
much smaller than Queen Isabella and her scientific

advisors did which was way he thought he could
make it across the empty Atlantic to India.

But Columbus's size estimate was wrong -- again,
just like Napoleon's height -- because of
mixed up units.

However, his error did send him West to become
the first European to discover America -- as

long as you ignore the hornless vikings who
beat him by 500 years.

comments.author: James Oldfield

comments.text:
+James Oldfield Taxonomy is not a language itself, so without Latin, it 
would not exist. Vatican City citizens (not sure if there's a denonym for 
that) still use Latin, but even if they got rid of it as an official 
language, studying Latin allows historians to continue to uncovering 
history of Ancient Rome. Western countries such as the United States, 
United Kingdom, and the majority of the European Union get the structure of 
their government, symbolism, and language directly and indirectly from the 
Roman Empire and Latin Language.

Latin has also been used in media and pop culture - for example, Pink Floyd 
did a dark side of the moon concert in Latin before, social media websites 
like Facebook offer Latin as a language to use the website in, highly 
successful video games like "Final Fantasy VII" and "The Binding of Isaac: 
Rebirth" have songs with Latin lyrics.

There's a lot you can do with Latin. The first, of course, being that you 
can speak it, you can use it to study history or progress organization in 
science, you can also study it to include it in media, and you can also 
study it to build a foundation for learning the five languages that stemmed 
directly from it, as well as getting a better understanding of English 
which indirectly comes from Latin.

As a Latin Scholar, I can safely say that you also will learn a lot of 
history, as well as ancient religion/mythology from learning it. That being 
said, it is an elective, so if Latin is not your cup of tea, don't take it, 
but it certainly is worth being provided as an option.

Of course you can't make as much use out of it as you could Spanish if 
you're looking to be bilingual. Spanish is a very dominant language in the 
world. The reasons that motivate people like myself to study Latin are a 
little different, but these reasons are certainly not nonexistent.
comments.author: VanillaHatVII

comments.text:

and Portuguese.

comments.text:
I imagine that if Lady Godiva did indeed ride through the town naked, there 
wouldn't be much furor over it, and it would be unlikely anyone would take 
enough note to write it down.  She lived in a culture in which nudity was 
not an issue.  Families still slept, and screwed, in common rooms.  People 
were regularly nude around one another and it wasn't too big of a deal, in 
fact the stupendous opposition to nudity and viewing nudity as inherently 
sexual didn't become widespread until much later.  If it happened, I would 
guess that the reason the husband would agree and figure the Lady would not 
do it would be that it was too cold or uncomfortable riding a horse nude.﻿

comments.text:
I find latin and greek both very useful in general, and I am glad that I 
have the option of taking them in school.
The most practical facet of it is that their structure has been a major 
help in learning german (declentions, and other grammatical similarities).
In addition to that, if I come across a word and I do not know what it 
means, I can often make an educated guess if I know the root word.
comments.author: Malcolm Rose-Zadow

comments.author: TheDaniHR1997

comments.text:
+Cian Cooney +TheDaniHR1997 The reasons for learning Latin in order to 
conform to something that uses an outdated convention, are the same as the 
reasons for using Imperial instead of Metric. Latin is not a prerequisite 
for serving/believing in/worshipping a god, but is there for the sole 
reason that it's traditional. The same meanings could be conveyed with any 
language, and any god who made us all would understand it.
Latin as a language, with its grammar, is not necessary to be a doctor, 
where all the latin names could just as easily be any other language. Words 
make sense because they attach themselves to other words in many ways. 
"Your 'perineum' is full of 'mercurium' and that's why you're sick", could 
just as easily be "Your 'behindtheballsplace' is full of 
'silverlookingstuff' and that's why you're sick". Once we know what a 
perineum is and what Mercurium is, we don't need to know that the words are 
even latin. 
And saying that you need to be taught a functionally dead language so you 
can potentially become a teacher of it in future, is not a valid reason. 
Have some people take evening classes when they finish high school or 
something. Also, Italian, Spanish, French, Portugese, and Romanian already 
has a set of grammatical rules in place that derive from Latin, and can 
fully stand on their own without it. 
Yay for reasoning!
comments.author: McJaews

comments.text:
about colombus... alguns historiadores afirmam que é possivel que a coroa 
Portuguesa soubesse previamente à partida de colombo para as Americas da 
existencia de uma massa terreste naquela zona e terem eviado um espião, 
colombo, (que era casado com uma poruguesa) para as cortes de castela, para 
poder retardar o mais que podesse a chegada destes ultimos à india, 
comercio que Portugal queria assegurar... podemos dizer: mas se os 
Portugueses já sabiam das Americas porque é que não as colonizaram em vez 
de as oferecerem de mão beijada aos Espanhois? a razão é simples, porque no 
momento em questão a população de Portugal não ultrapassava os 1,000,000 de 
habitantes o que tornava qualquer processo de colonização bastante demorado 
e quase impossivel, então a coroa Portuguesa, que tinha imposto uma lei de 
secretismo sobre as descubertas maritimas (como era de costume na epoca), 
decidio guardar para si o conhecimento das americas, enviar os Espanhois à 
caça aogambozino e assim assegurar o rentavel negocio da India... mas isto 
são somente teorias...﻿

comments.text:
Columbus: a goodfella who discovered a hemisphere that was inhabited with 
people who didn't write, and also didn't invent anything. Thus the dude who 
we can accurately say "discovered" the hemisphere because when he happened 
upon it, it actually mattered.
What did the tribals do with their discovery? Nothing, so why is everyone 
hating on the poor guy?
Yeah the Vikings did it first, and I'd like to hear about why word didn't 
spread, especially since they actually set up shop. It's in the Poetic Edda 
isn't it? ﻿
comments.author: Wolfgang Oberlander

comments.text: set up a shop?, in the poetic Edda?, you´ve got this horribly wrong.
comments.author: oliskranz

comments.text:
They didn't write? What the fuck?
The population of pre-Colombian North America is estimated to be around 20 
million people. The Incas developed a very interesting system of knots for 
mathematical operations and possibly for some kind of record-keeping. When 
Columbus found the American continent, there were native cities bigger than 
Milan, Madrid, Lisboa or other big cities in Europe(both continentes, 
however, were vastly dwarfed by China at the time, that was a bastion of 
technological development through much of history while Europe was busy in 
a cultural mosh-pit of frenzied killing and raping).
What did the tribals do with their discovery? Well, they, huh, populated 
it? There is evidence that in less than a 1000 years they spread over 
13.000 kilometers from Northern Montana, just south of the Ice Sheets 
covering Canada at the time, to the tip of Patagonia, at the other side of 
the globe. They formed actual complex societies, trade routes, developed 
agriculture not one but two and possibly three times independently(if you 
want to know, once in the Mississipi valley, once in Mexico and possibly 
but still debatably in the Amazon valley; compare that to *no* times 
agriculture was discovered in Europe: it was actually first developed in 
the Middle East and other parts of Eastern Asia, such as Anatolia and 
Egypt, then later independently created in China, then still later on 
independently in Papua New Guinea and possibly twice but certainly once in 
Sub-Saharan Africa), they had advanced engineering, mathematics and 
astronomy. You make them out to be a bunch of rock-banging barbarians that 
deserved to be "civilized", when they were not.

And lastly, about the vikings. Their colonization was not widespread 
because there was one giant bottleneck between their relatively poor 
kingdoms in Scandinavia and Iceland, and the Americas: Greenland. It was 
hard to navigate near Greenland, when it was possible at all, the 
agriculture there was utter shite so it couldn't sustain a big population, 
trading trips from Iceland and Norway were pretty rare so they needed to 
make do with what they had(and even then a big part of it was sent to 
Europe, mainly walrus tusks and bear skins, to be traded for gold), and 
even without those factors Iceland was pretty damn isolated from the rest 
of Europe. They just didn't have a whole lot of casual contact with anyone 
not from Norway, so that's why word didn't spread. They didn't have the 
money, the people or the time to do it. To add insult to injury, the 
natives they found there were either hostile like in Greenland, or just 
plain disinterested in the vikings.
comments.author: Kaiser Fred VIII

comments.author: Pikarine Plays

comments.text:
Here are 5 other historical misconceptions to add
1. Cleopatra was not beautiful, but then again do you have to be to bed 
with Caesar?
2. The Parthenon was not always viewed as a great structure like how we do 
today. In fact at the time, many Greeks hated it--Plato didn't like it at 
all.
3. Nero did not fiddle while Rome burned, but he did play a lyre a sing a 
lament of the Fall of Troy, but not for reasons you'd suppose.
4. Hannibal Barca was not as great a general as history has suggested. A 
lot of his successes were on luck, and Scipio's family hyped up the image 
of Hannibal to make Scipio look cooler, or something of that nature.
5. Genghis Kahn did not conquer all the areas of the Mongol Empire contrary 
to popular belief. The Empire's expansion reached it peak under his 
successor Ogedei Kahn.﻿
